title: 103_hr3668
content:
The Act is titled the "American Museum of Natural History 125th Anniversary Commemorative Coin Act" and specifies the coin specifications. The Secretary of the Treasury will issue up to 600,000 one-dollar silver coins, each weighing 26.73 grams, with a diameter of 1.500 inches, and composed of 90% silver and 10% copper. The design of the coins will feature a prehistoric dinosaur emblematic of the American Museum of Natural History, with inscriptions including the year "1995" and words like "Liberty" and "In". The coins minted under this Act in 1995 will feature a prehistoric dinosaur emblematic of the American Museum of Natural History, with inscriptions including "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". These coins will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. The Secretary will obtain silver for the coins from stockpiles established under the Strategic and Critical Minerals Stock Piling Act. The design for each coin will be selected by the Secretary after consultation with the American Museum of Natural History and the Commission of Fine Arts, and reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF THE COINS.

Coins minted under this Act may be issued by the Secretary starting on January 1, 1995 and must cease minting by December 31, 1995. Only one U.S. Mint facility can strike each quality of the coins, which will be available in uncirculated and proof qualities.

SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS.

The Secretary will sell the coins at a price including face value, a surcharge, and design costs. Bulk sales will have discounts, and prepaid orders will also receive discounts. A $10.00 surcharge per coin is included in all sales. SEC. 7. GENERAL WAIVER OF PROCUREMENT REGULATIONS.

No procurement laws apply to goods and services for this Act, except for equal employment opportunity laws.

SEC. 8. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES.

Surcharges from coin sales go to the Budgetary Fund for the American Museum of Natural History.

SEC. 9. AUDITS. SEC. 9. AUDITS. The Comptroller General can examine the Budgetary Fund of the American Museum of Natural History related to expenditures under section 8. SEC. 10. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. SEC. 10. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. The Secretary must ensure minting coins won't cost the government. Coins can only be issued if payment is received, security is provided, or a guarantee of payment from a qualified institution is in place.
